definition: public/collectively owned/common/international (e.g. high seas, metric system, calendar)/make public/fair/just/Duke, highest of five orders of nobility 五等爵位[wu3 deng3 jue2 wei4]/honorable (gentlemen)/father-in-law/male (animal)
flat/level/equal/to tie (make the same score)/to draw (score)/calm/peaceful/see also 平聲|平声[ping2 sheng1]
to hand over/to deliver/to pay (money)/to turn over/to make friends/to intersect (lines)/variant of 跤[jiao1]
easy/amiable/to change/to exchange/prefix corresponding to the English adjective suffix "-able" or "-ible"
surname Yi/abbr. for 易經|易经[Yi4 jing1], the Book of Changes

sentences.english: Britain’s Office of Fair Trading has already ruled some bank charges unfair.
sentences.chinese: 英國的公平交易委員會，已經判定某些銀行交易不公。
做一個公平交易的情人。

sentences.english: Each party must act in accordance with good faith and fair dealing.
sentences.chinese: 各方當事人均須依誠實信用和公平交易而行爲。

sentences.english: A number of stocks on the OTCBB have fair-trading.
sentences.chinese: 一些股票的場外交易公告牌代碼有公平交易。

sentences.english: Never lie,cheat or steal,always strike a fair deal.
sentences.chinese: 決不撒謊，欺瞞或偷盜，堅守公平交易。

definition: to force sb to buy or sell/to trade using coercion
cheating neither old nor young (idiom); treating youngsters and old folk equally scrupulously/Our house offers sincere treatment to all and fair trade to old and young alike.
received and paid for (business term)/the goods delivered and the bill settled
to take advantage of sb's precarious position
